data.title: Revisiting 'Love Actually' and what makes a good Christmas movie : It's Been a Minute : NPR
data.meta_description: It's been almost two decades since the star-studded romantic comedy premiered, but Love Actually is still a holiday staple that plays in both movie theaters and living rooms across the country. Since the film is here to stay, we feel it's about time to see how it holds up. Host Brittany Luse chats with NPR Weekend Edition's Ayesha Rascoe, who saw the film for the first time this year. They also break down what defines the Christmas movie genre – and its surprising overlap with horror.You can follow us on Twitter @NPRItsBeenAMin and email us at ibam@npr.org.
data.text:
BRITTANY LUSE, HOST:

Just a heads-up - this episode contains mentions of sex and sexual assault and some language that might not be suitable for everyone.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

AYESHA RASCOE, BYLINE: I'm not immune to love. I'm just - I don't seek it out. I am worried that it's going to mess up my algorithm. I hope they don't start showing me, like, romantic comedies.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: No. Don't mess up my algorithm with this.

LUSE: You going to be watching "27 Dresses."

RASCOE: (Laughter) No. Please...

LUSE: You going to be watching "The Holiday."

RASCOE: ...Please do not recommend me no more...

LUSE: Yes.

RASCOE: ...Like this.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: You're listening to IT'S BEEN A MINUTE from NPR. I'm Brittany Luse. And today, in this most merry of episodes, I'm joined by none other than one of the host of Weekend Edition and a returning friend of the show, Ayesha Rascoe. How are you doing?

RASCOE: I'm doing all right. How are you?

LUSE: I'm good. I'm so excited that you are here today for this because this is unfinished business.

RASCOE: Yes.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: Ayesha first came on the show back in October. And after we had her on, we asked her to embark on a journey of discovery for us because she'd been sitting out on a big cultural phenomenon. So in the very first episode that I hosted of this show, there was a big reveal. And the big reveal was that...

RASCOE: (Laughter).

LUSE: ...You had never seen "Love Actually" - extremely popular Christmas movie that came out...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...Nearly 20 years ago. But things have changed.

RASCOE: Yes, things have changed. I had never seen this movie. I had heard talk of it. I'd kind of walked in on parts of it, and I was like, what is this crap?

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: I was like, uh. But I have watched it now.

LUSE: Now, for those of you who also somehow haven't seen "Love Actually," or who maybe need a refresher, it's a romantic comedy set in London that follows nine interconnected stories, all about the complexities of love - from childhood crushes to unrequited passion to infidelities to love at first sight. And it's kind of a who's who of British stars - Hugh Grant, Colin Firth, Emma Thompson, Liam Neeson, Keira Knightley, Bill Nighy. The list goes on. Finally, and this is the reason we're talking about it now, it takes place during Christmas.

OK. Let's recap what was said when you were on the show last. We can just play a little moment.

(SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED NPR BROADCAST)

RASCOE: The type of movies I like to watch, they usually involve murder or a...

LUSE: (Laughter).

RASCOE: ...Supernatural killer or...

UNIDENTIFIED PERSON: (Laughter).

RASCOE: ...The U.K. prime minister running from a zombie. I have not seen "Love Actually."

LUSE: What?

ASMA KHALID: You haven't seen "Love Actually?" OK.

RASCOE: I don't like love.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: This is something people don't know about me. I do not...

LUSE: Ayesha.

RASCOE: ...Like love movies.

LUSE: That's not really what the movie is about.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: It's about Christmas.

RASCOE: Well, I believe in love personally, but I don't like to see it. It's like, ugh, romantic comedies. Oh, they're falling in love. Who cares?

LUSE: Oh, my God.

RASCOE: Where is the killing?

(SOUNDBITE OF ELECTRONIC SCRATCHING SOUND)

LUSE: So...

RASCOE: Yes. That's how I felt. That's how I felt. That's how I feel.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: So the movie didn't shift any needles for you.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: On today's show, Ayesha's take on "Love Actually," plus what the holiday movie genre gives that other films don't after this quick break.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: OK, OK, OK. Now that we have covered your past feelings...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...You know, in the BLA - before "Love Actually"...

RASCOE: (Laughter) Yes.

LUSE: ...Now we're in a new era. What's your overall reaction now that you've seen it?

RASCOE: OK. It was too long.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: It is over two hours.

RASCOE: Let's start with that.

LUSE: The runtime is lengthy.

RASCOE: Why is there so many people?

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: Like, why do we care about all these people? We could've cut a few characters.

LUSE: We need to do "Love Actually," Ayesha's cut. That's what we need.

RASCOE: You know, I did see Liam Neeson, and he wasn't going after any kidnappers. And I felt like that was a waste.

LUSE: Oh, I feel like that was a disappointment for you.

RASCOE: It was a disappointment. It was a disappointment. And of course, I saw the guy who played Rick in "Walking Dead," and I realized oh, OK.

LUSE: Oh, right - Andrew Lincoln.

RASCOE: Andrew Lincoln. There were no zombies. So I feel like he was underutilized as well. And I just felt like a lot of these people - they didn't have good boundaries.

LUSE: No, OK.

RASCOE: But I got it. I mean, I get why people like it, right? I felt like it leaned into the cheesiness, but I appreciate that because I feel like if you're going to do it, then do it. You know, put your whole - put your back into it. You know what I'm saying? Put your whole...

LUSE: Yes. Yes.

RASCOE: ...Into...

LUSE: Yes.

RASCOE: And I feel like it did that. I do wonder if part of the charm of it is, you know, the fact that it was, like, British and, like, Americans are watching it, and we just love those little accents.

LUSE: That is true.

RASCOE: And it...

LUSE: That is true.

RASCOE: It made it very posh. And there were parts where my heart was softened. I did...

LUSE: OK.

RASCOE: ...Feel a little - I had parts where my heart was softened.

LUSE: OK. Give me an example of a part that softened your heart.

RASCOE: I did like the little boy. He fell in love, and he said, love is agony.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

LIAM NEESON: (As Daniel) I'm a little relieved.

THOMAS BRODIE-SANGSTER: (As Sam) Why?

NEESON: (As Daniel) Well, because I thought it would be something worse.

BRODIE-SANGSTER: (As Sam) Worse than the total agony of being in love?

RASCOE: I thought it was cute. Like, I thought those interactions were cute. I think longing for someone is, like - see, I think that's a universal thing. The part that really softened my heart was the guy who was - his brother slept with his wife.

LUSE: Oh, Colin Firth - his character, Jamie.

RASCOE: Colin Firth.

LUSE: Right, right, right.

RASCOE: Jamie, when he proposed to the Portuguese lady and in his bad Portuguese, and you're reading the subtitles.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

COLIN FIRTH: (As Jamie Bennett, speaking Portuguese).

RASCOE: It touched my little heart.

LUSE: Oh.

RASCOE: It touched my heart.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

LUCIA MONIZ: (As Aurelia) Yes is be my answer.

RASCOE: I felt a little like, aw, like a little - this is - even though it was crazy, it made no sense. It made...

LUSE: Right.

RASCOE: ...Zero sense. It was just like, aw, that is sweet.

LUSE: 'Cause they just - 'cause literally, they had a language barrier. He could only have known her for about - what? - a month?

RASCOE: He didn't know her at all. She was cleaning his rental home.

LUSE: Yeah, they had - maybe had 30 minutes of conversation, total, probably.

RASCOE: But not really. I mean, 'cause they didn't speak the same language, but they were in love somehow. Like, that's the thing about this movie. Everybody's in love.

LUSE: (Laughter).

RASCOE: Just, like, you look at the person - I love you.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: You're the love of my life.

LUSE: You know, one of the things that has come up as we were discussing the film as a group, the film really is told through a white male gaze, which, I mean...

RASCOE: Oh, yes.

LUSE: ...Yeah.

RASCOE: Yeah, yeah (laughter).

LUSE: That's 150% true.

RASCOE: Yes. With the Prime Minister, it was like, OK, so he falls in love with Natalie, who was - I guess she was, like, the caterer, but didn't it seem like she was delivering official documents? But then they...

LUSE: Right.

RASCOE: (Laughter).

LUSE: I rewatched it earlier. When they're introducing her, they're like, this is Natalie - didn't explain what her job was. But all she did was serve him. She served him...

RASCOE: She just served him.

LUSE: ...All of his meals.

RASCOE: And she gave him...

LUSE: ...Served him envelopes.

RASCOE: ...Papers.

LUSE: Right. For other people, like Ayesha of the past, who haven't seen the film, there is a key point. The president of the United States is visiting the prime minister, played by Hugh Grant, of the U.K. And they're supposed to have, like, some general diplomacy meeting. We don't even really know what they're talking about. The details are not important at all. And the president of the United States, played by Billy Bob Thornton, has some very untoward behavior and gets in the personal body-buffer zone of Miss Natalie, the woman that the prime minister has taken a little shine to.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

BILLY BOB THORNTON: (As the U.S. President) Natalie, I hope to see much more of you as our two great countries work toward a better future.

MARTINE MCCUTCHEON: (As Natalie) Thank you, sir.

LUSE: And he gives this speech to the British press saying how, like, we no longer have a special relationship with the United States.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

HUGH GRANT: (As the Prime Minister) I fear that this has become a bad relationship.

RASCOE: Yeah, this is what Hugh Grant says - we're a strong country. Even though we're not as powerful, we are still a mighty whatever it was (laughter).

LUSE: Yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

GRANT: (As the Prime Minister) We may be a small country, but we're a great one, too - country of Shakespeare, Churchill, the Beatles, Sean Connery, Harry Potter.

LUSE: And it was like - because we didn't know what the conflict was or what they were meeting about...

RASCOE: (Laughter) Yes.

LUSE: ...Like, diplomacy-wise, the speech is really him being like, you're not going to mess with my woman.

RASCOE: Yes.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

GRANT: (As the Prime Minister) And since bullies only respond to strength, from now onward, I will be prepared to be much stronger, and the president should be prepared for that.

RASCOE: That was sexual assault. That was not right. But, you know, I felt like we were going to war with Britain. We no longer have a special relationship? That's 200 years.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: OK. So I had an issue with that. And even Andrew Lincoln, who was kind of creepy with his friend's wife.

LUSE: OK?

RASCOE: We haven't gotten...

LUSE: Yes.

RASCOE: ...To that. Yeah.

LUSE: Right - who was played by Keira Knightley when she was, like, 18, 17 years old?

RASCOE: Oh, wow. She did look young.

LUSE: Yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

KEIRA KNIGHTLEY: (As Juliet) But you never talk to me. You don't like me.

ANDREW LINCOLN: (As Mark) It's a self-preservation thing, you see.

RASCOE: I mean, I was glad to find out about the cards thing, the famous thing where he's standing outside, holding the cards outside the door.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

UNIDENTIFIED MUSICAL ARTIST: (Singing) Shepherds quake at the sight.

RASCOE: But now seeing it, it's like, so what were they - what was supposed to happen with this? What? He's just in love with his friend's wife? And - but he never talks to her, so how is he in love? You know? It's...

LUSE: Right. Right. Like, all they talked about the whole movie - he hates her. He's avoiding her.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: He don't want to be bothered with her. And then he shows up to their house and has all these cue cards.

RASCOE: (Laughter) Cue cards.

LUSE: And he's telling her, I love you so much, playing this...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: It was weird.

RASCOE: And it was creepy 'cause, like, why would you take pictures of her at the wedding and only just zoom in on her face? That's weird. That's creepy.

LUSE: It's weird.

RASCOE: And when you talk about the white male gaze, he says she's, like, practically perfect or whatever. She's perfect, but you don't talk to her. You don't deal with her. That's part of the issue. She's a perfect figure that you can look at and not hear from, right? Like, the perfect woman is that woman that you stare at but does not interact with you (laughter).

LUSE: It's...

RASCOE: You see what I'm saying?

LUSE: It's very problematic.

RASCOE: Yes. That's not what love is. Love is not staring in the eyes of somebody wistfully. Love is, like, doing the laundry. But you can't make no movie about that, so I get it. I get it. But that's...

LUSE: (Laughter).

RASCOE: That was (laughter) my issue.

LUSE: Yeah. You know, I never watched it thinking, like, yeah, this is what relationships are supposed to be like.

RASCOE: (Laughter) No.

LUSE: However, the older I get, there is, like, a big theme in the film of, like, male boss/female employee.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: Like Hugh Grant, prime minister, with Natalie.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: Natalie...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...With no real job title. It's like, the perfect woman - she's bringing you biscuits. She's bringing your mail.

RASCOE: And then the one with Colin Firth, who she...

LUSE: Right.

RASCOE: ...She was cleaning the house, so she was working for him.

LUSE: And at one point, he loses a manuscript in the pond behind his...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...House. And she strips down to her underwear.

RASCOE: And jumps in there. And it's a...

LUSE: Cold water.

RASCOE: And in the cold water.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

FIRTH: (As Jamie Bennett) Oh, God, she's in. Right. And now, she'll think I'm a total spaz if I don't go in, too.

RASCOE: And I should say my husband did see parts of this 'cause I was watching this in multiple places, 'cause, like I said, I got a lot...

LUSE: Yes.

RASCOE: ...Going on. My husband watched that part of it. He was like, oh, you would never jump in the water for me. And I was like...

LUSE: (Laughter).

RASCOE: No, I sure wouldn't (laughter).

LUSE: And that's why it's a movie. That's why it's a movie.

RASCOE: (Laughter) It's a movie.

LUSE: And even...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...Alan Rickman, the boss guy who has...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...This executive assistant who's hitting on Alan Rickman all the time, and eventually, he's hitting back. You know what...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...I'm saying? He's into it.

RASCOE: Yeah, yeah, yeah.

LUSE: He's catching the affection. He likes it.

RASCOE: It is inappropriate. It's inappropriate.

LUSE: It's inappropriate.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: But I have to say, Emma Thompson as Alan Rickman's wife - her performance is so good.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

EMMA THOMPSON: (As Karen) Imagine your husband bought a gold necklace and, come Christmas, gave it to somebody else.

LUSE: She was good.

RASCOE: She did a great job.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

ALAN RICKMAN: (As Harry) I'm so in the wrong - a classic fool.

THOMPSON: (As Karen) Yes, but you've also made a fool out of me. You've made the life I lead foolish, too.

LUSE: And she still shows up to the kids' Christmas pageant. Now, I will say, if that had been me, I would have been blowing off the children's Christmas pageant. I wouldn't even have been there.

RASCOE: Oh, I would've. Like, it would have been...

LUSE: Yelling, screaming...

RASCOE: I would've - yelling, screaming, like...

LUSE: ...Making a scene.

RASCOE: ...As soon as I realize, like, let me call my mama to take the kids to this thing 'cause it's...

LUSE: Exactly.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: ...'Cause I'm about to set it off.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: Literally. Same. I was like - again, that must be that Britishness, 'cause I was like, someone like me?

RASCOE: Uh-uh. First, I'm going to be like, so who'd you buy the necklace for? Did you buy it for that ho at the office? Oh, and then...

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: That's going to go in the podcast edit.

RASCOE: (Laughter) No, I could not have held it in to go to the children's thing. I wish I could be that together as a mother, but I just would have been like, kids, I need y'all to go to the other room.

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: Also, they also kept saying - going back to Natalie for a second - did you pick up on the fact that they kept calling her fat the whole movie?

RASCOE: Oh, yeah, that was my other issue. Like, why are they fat-shaming Natalie? This was my direct question in my book right here. It was insane.

LUSE: It didn't make any sense. I couldn't see it. It's like, the fact that it was so fat-phobic in general...

RASCOE: My goodness.

LUSE: And then on top of that, the film is not diverse. And that didn't necessarily surprise me for, like, a...

RASCOE: No, no.

LUSE: ...Mainstream Christmas romantic comedy in 2003.

RASCOE: No.

LUSE: 2022. However, you know, there's very few characters of color in this film, despite being set in one of the most diverse cities...

RASCOE: No.

LUSE: ...You know, in the UK, I imagine. And most of the characters of color who do show up are kind of in the typical role...

RASCOE: They're side - yeah.

LUSE: ...The sidekick, the - I couldn't tell whether this Black woman was the prime minister's chief of staff. They don't - they barely give anybody a job in this film...

RASCOE: No (laughter). No.

LUSE: ...But the assistant, you know? And then at the very end, the young Black woman who's the gifted performer...

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

OLIVIA OLSON: (As Joanna Anderson, singing) All I want for Christmas is you.

LUSE: It's interesting, now that I'm watching it, looking specifically and thinking about that - yeah, it definitely hits different in 2022 because I feel like audiences have grown. I have grown to expect more...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...From the films I see.

RASCOE: To expect more. Yeah.

(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)

LUSE: Next up - what Ayesha really thinks about folks who love "Love Actually" and why even bad Christmas movies are still so good.

(SOUNDBITE OF ELECTRONIC SCRATCHING SOUND)

LUSE: So we've established that "Love Actually" has some problems.

RASCOE: Just a little bit.

LUSE: But still, it's one of the most popular and most beloved Christmas movies of the 2000s - perhaps all time. And I'm going to give you some stats right now to back this up.

RASCOE: OK, OK.

LUSE: OK. When it came out in 2003, it grossed almost $200 million. It was nominated for a Golden Globe for best motion picture musical or comedy.

RASCOE: OK.

LUSE: I mean, "Love Actually" is still showing in theaters in 2022.

RASCOE: Yeah. When I looked it up, and it was like, show times. And you can see, like, that it was at movie theaters for people who want to see it, so...

LUSE: Yeah. There are plenty of writers who have been defending this film for years in, like, real serious publications of note.

RASCOE: I mean, it's a big deal. And this is something I will say - even though I might sound a little Grinchy throughout this, I don't believe in knocking what people love. I think it's not great to be that person where everybody is talking about they love whoever - Taylor Swift - and you come in and go like, I don't think she's that great. It's like...

LUSE: I'm that person.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: I'm like - and I'm like, OK, didn't nobody ask you. Who cares what you think? We're happy. Like, I don't want to rain on people's parade. If you love "Love Actually," that is great. That is great for you. You can love "Love Actually." I support you in that.

LUSE: That is beautiful, Ayesha. You have, you know, hit upon something. I mean, love it or hate it, this film is a part of the culture.

RASCOE: Yes. Mmm hmm.

LUSE: It's officially part of the Christmas canon. So, you know, even if one doesn't love the film, it is loved, actually.

RASCOE: (Laughter) I like how you did that. I like how you did that.

LUSE: OK. It's - teamwork makes the dream work over here, OK?

RASCOE: (Laughter).

LUSE: That line was a group effort. So on the point of Christmas, when we first discussed this film months ago...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...I said, it's not about romance. It's about Christmas.

RASCOE: Yep. Christmas.

LUSE: And it is - you're right. It is actually about love.

RASCOE: Well, because...

LUSE: It is kind of about Christmas - well, I have thoughts about how Christmasy the film is 'cause that also was a point of contention...

RASCOE: (Laughter).

LUSE: ...Within the team, where not everybody agreed on how Christmasy the film was or not. Do you feel like the film has much actual Christmas cheer? Like, beyond the setting, is it really about Christmas, you think?

RASCOE: I think it has a lot of Christmas cheer - right? - the Christmas parties, the Christmas performances, and, like, the Christmas music. I do think it was weird, the way they tried to say that Christmas is a time to, like, tell the truth.

LUSE: (Laughter).

RASCOE: And I'm like, what? It was basically like, Christmas is a time to tell hard truths. And I'm like...

LUSE: Is it?

RASCOE: ...Is it? It's like, it's - Christmas is a time to hit on your best friend's wife. Is that the meaning of Christmas?

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: I'm like...

LUSE: They didn't give me that one in Sunday school, actually, I don't think.

RASCOE: I didn't know that was what Baby Jesus was all about - you know? - saying, I need to tell you the truth 'cause it's Christmas. I didn't know that Christmas was a time for hard, unsettling truth.

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: But I do think there was a lot of Christmas. And I think the way that some of it is so, like, unbelievable - I think that's Christmas, right? Like, it's like, oh, the prime minister's coming to the neighborhood. And then the boy running to the airport to see the little girl.

LUSE: His - yeah, his crush and - yeah.

RASCOE: His crush.

LUSE: He's doing all these flips and...

RASCOE: Yeah, his...

LUSE: Yeah.

RASCOE: ...Flips. It was very unsafe in that airport. Very unsafe.

(SOUNDBITE OF FILM, "LOVE ACTUALLY")

BRODIE-SANGSTER: (As Sam) Joanna.

OLSON: (As Joanna Anderson) Sam?

BRODIE-SANGSTER: (As Sam) I thought you didn't know my name.

OLSON: (As Joanna Anderson) Of course I do.

RASCOE: You know that whole thing - like, I felt like that feels like Christmas to me. Like, Christmas magic - that's what that felt like to me.

LUSE: Mmm. Christmas magic.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: You know, some of the adoration and the criticism about "Love Actually" can be applied to the whole Christmas genre. And I kind of want to take a second to look at what makes the genre. So we have the Christmas romance film - movies like "The Holiday," "The Perfect Holiday," "The Best Man Holiday," and, of course, "Love Actually." But the Christmas film genre is so much bigger than those. Like, we have "Bad Moms Christmas," "Home Alone," the "Last Holiday," "The Family Stone." These films are markedly different than, like, the Christmas romance film, but they all hit some of the same marks. To your point, they give you that feeling of Christmas magic, like everything...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: ...Works out in the end in these films, like...

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: There's...

RASCOE: Yeah.

LUSE: ...Not really any stakes.

RASCOE: No.

LUSE: There's also all these themes...

RASCOE: Yeah.

LUSE: ...Of home and family and bringing people together. I feel like those are the kind of things that I'm gravitating toward at the end of the year, when, at least where I live, it's cold, and I really need that winter break away from work.

RASCOE: Yes.

LUSE: And I feel like these films are, like, exactly what I'm looking for in those moments.

RASCOE: I can see that. I can see that. I think I can see how it's very comforting. They're feelgood. They're light. You don't have to think a whole lot. And there's not, like, a whole lot of sadness, and - although some of them have sad parts. So I do get that. Now, for me, like, when I am like, I just need to really get away, I'm like, I want to watch something with, like, a satanic cult or something. I want something like...

(LAUGHTER)

LUSE: That's your release.

RASCOE: That's my release. Like, that's what I've been watching all - I just need a break from - work has just been too much. I can't even do reality TV too much. I'm like, I want to watch something scary, crazy, you know, just out of this world.

LUSE: Like a Christmas slasher...

RASCOE: Christmas slasher...

LUSE: ...Exorcism.

RASCOE: ...Exorcism, demonic possession, you know, like, that sort of thing. You know, I had to cleanse my palate after "Love Actually." I'm like, let me watch "Cabinet Of Curiosities". It's like...

(LAUGHTER)

RASCOE: I'm like let me look at this killer painting. OK. Whoo (ph), that's crazy. So that's how I - but I understand why people would watch Christmas movies. I get it. I get it. Yeah.

LUSE: You know - so I love Christmas movies. I watch the family ones. I never miss a "Home Alone" every year. I'm watching all of the Lifetime, you know, holiday films that they put out every year. I watch the ones on Netflix. I watch them on all the streamers. I'm obsessed.

RASCOE: Yes. OK.

LUSE: And I realized that, like, I have, like, almost a different, like, matrix for deciding whether or not, like, those films are good. It's almost like what makes, like, a general, you know, film good is that there's narrative tension. And you get all caught up in the story, and you don't know what's going to happen next. And I love those movies, but...

RASCOE: OK.

LUSE: ...When it comes to, like, Christmas films - especially Christmas romances - it's almost like I judge them by a different standard. It's like that lack of tension is...

RASCOE: OK.
